stem: A 28-year-old client is being treated for severe preeclampsia with a Magnesium Sulfate infusion. During the hourly assessment, she is difficult to rouse. Based on the documentation in the Magnesium Monitoring & Toxicity Flowsheet tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Suspected magnesium overdose.
Background: Receiving Mag at 2g/hr for 18 hours.
Assessment: Client responds only to painful stimuli. Muscle tone is flaccid.
Recommendation: Immediate reversal and airway protection.

tabs.title: Magnesium Toxicity Flowsheet
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingInterpretation
Deep Tendon Reflexes0 (Absent)Magnesium Toxicity
Respiratory Rate9 bpm (Shallow)Severe Depression
Urine Output10 mL / hr (for 4 hrs)Oliguria (Risk for toxic build-up)
Blood Pressure92/54 mmHgHypotension

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 92/54, HR 58, RR 9, T 98.2°F. SpO2 88% on RA.

actionOptions.text: Stop the Magnesium Sulfate infusion immediately
Administer Calcium Gluconate IV as prescribed (Antidote)
Increase the IV rate of Magnesium to stabilize the BP
Perform a 'vigorous' fundal massage to rouse the client

parameterOptions.text: Respiratory rate and continuous pulse oximetry
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This client has Magnesium Sulfate Toxicity (c2), as evidenced by the 'Toxic Triad': Absent reflexes (0), Respiratory depression (<12), and Decreased level of consciousness. The oliguria (10 mL/hr) likely caused the drug to accumulate to toxic levels. Priority #1 is stopping the infusion (a1) and Priority #2 is administering the antidote, Calcium Gluconate (a2). Key parameters are the RR (p1) to track airway safety and DTRs (p2) to track neuromuscular recovery.
clinicalPearls: Reflexes disappear FIRST (at ~9–12 mg/dL), followed by respiratory depression (at ~12–15 mg/dL).
Magnesium is the 'muscle relaxant'—toxicity leads to everything going 'limp' (muscles, heart, lungs).
Always have Calcium Gluconate at the bedside when magnesium is infusing.

questionTrap.trap: Calling a Rapid Response before stopping the infusion.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Stopping the infusion is the FIRST action! If you leave it running while waiting for help, the patient will stop breathing.

mnemonic.title: B-U-R-P (Mag Toxicity)
mnemonic.expansion: B-BP Decreased. U-Urine Output low (<30). R-Reflexes absent. P-Pulmonary (RR < 12).
